column1: Ipswich Town beat AZ Alkmaar to win the Football League trophy, after a 3-0 win in the first leg and a 4-2 defeat in the second leg in Amsterdam. Butcher played for the Ipswich team that won the cup final on aggregate. He has also been part of a charity cycling team that made a round trip to Holland to raise money for Prostate Cancer UK and the Ipswich Town Academy.

The town was hit by multiple storms, including a severe weather event on 27 January, which caused major issues. The full cost of repairing the damage has not yet been calculated, but the council will receive support under the Bellwin Scheme. However, the local authority will have to contribute 0.2% of their net revenue budget, which amounts to £508,000. A report outlining the 240 pieces of work that need to be done to fix the problems has been presented to the council's executive committee.

Thomas Cook Airlines will begin a weekly flight between Glasgow and Las Vegas next summer. The airline's Airbus A330 fleet will operate the service between May and October. This is the first time Scotland has had a regular service to Las Vegas. The airline also announced an additional flight to Tunisia for the summer of 2015.

Roy Hodgson's Wales and Northern Ireland are in pot one with Wales and Northern Ireland in pot four. The Republic of Ireland's play-off is next, and if they win, they will be in pot three or pot four, depending on other results. England, Euro 2012 finalists Italy, the Czech Republic, and Wales or Northern Ireland are potential opponents in the play-off draw. The seedings are based on Uefa's national team coefficient rankings. The other top seeds for the finals are holders Spain, hosts France, world champions Germany, Portugal, and Belgium. The draw for the finals takes place on December 12th.

Damon Smith, who has Asperger's syndrome and a keen interest in guns and other weapons, was charged with making and possessing an Improvised Explosive Device (IED) that was intended to endanger the lives of people on the Jubilee Line train. The prosecution said the device contained ball bearings to act as shrapnel, increasing its destructive effect. The court heard that Mr Smith initially told police he had built a device to produce smoke, but later added ball bearings to make it look like a real bomb. The device was found by two passengers and passed on to a driver, who realized it contained two wires coming out of the back of a clock. The trial continues.

Lindhurst scheme, which includes up to 1,700 homes and various amenities, faced more than 140 objections from protesters. The planning committee voted five in favor, five against, with the chairman in favor. The developers of the project said it would bring major benefits to the local economy, including up to 4,000 jobs. However, concerns from Nottingham Wildlife Trust and Ramblers Association were raised regarding the potential loss of countryside and habitat.
The UN has announced that Europe has the world's worst record of throwing away fish. Almost a quarter of all catches go back overboard dead because they are not the fish the crews wanted to catch.

Palm's WebOS operating system, which was created to power smartphones and tablets, has been acquired by HP for $1.2bn (Â£789m). LG will receive the source code, engineers working on it, documentation and the websites promoting it. HP will also hold on to patents underlying WebOS and technology that helps it connect to web-based services. The acquisition is likely driven by LG's recognition that it needs to make gadgets of all types easier to use and the use of core web technology left it well placed for the next generation of mobile apps.

U's striker Joe Pigott cancelled out Andre Dozzell's opener in the 89th minute after Town lost the ball. McCarthy was furious and said "I'm not tolerating that. To concede that goal is really poor." Ipswich finished fifth in the Championship last season, four points outside the play-off places.

A recent study at the British Library has suggested that the deterioration of the author's sight may have been caused by heavy metal arsenic in medicine she took, which could also have contributed to her early death. The three pairs of glasses, kept in Jane Austen's writing desk, were examined using a portable lens meter to determine the strength of the lenses, which increased in strength from +1.75 to +4.75 and +5.0 in the final pair, making it difficult for her to see well enough to read or write by the time she died. The British Library is inviting optometrists to offer their opinions on the new theory.

The Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, has announced that the Easter Sunday date may change in the future. An act of Parliament in the UK allows for Easter Sunday to be fixed on the first Sunday after the second Saturday in April, but this has never been activated. Welby is in talks with Pope Francis, Coptic leader Pope Tawadros, and the leader of the Orthodox church Patriarch Bartholomew. He hopes the change will happen "in between five and 10 years time", but warned that the first attempt to make such a change was in the 10th Century. An Anglican source told the BBC there had been 15 attempts to agree a common date since then, with the Orthodox church following the Julian calendar. The Vatican approved a proposal for a fixed date in 1990, which was subject to agreement with other Christian churches and governments, but it has not yet been reached.

The latest report by Ulster Bank suggests that business activity in Northern Ireland has declined in April, with output and new orders declining. The decline follows three previous monthly declines in the last five months. However, the report also notes that despite the weakness, companies are continuing to hire staff. The construction sector posted its largest fall in business activity in two years, while retailers reported their sharpest decline in retail sales since May 2012. The report's chief economist, Richard Ramsey, stated that while the decline in business activity in Northern Ireland compared to other UK regions is modest, the country's manufacturing sector continues to perform well.

The shop in Penarth, Vale of Glamorgan has been targeted by opponents since it opened in November. The party now invites its "anarchist friends" to aim their eggs at posters of Mr Farage and Cardiff South and Penarth candidate John Rees-Evans. A UKIP spokesperson said no eggs had been thrown since the posters were put up.

The opening night of One Man, Two Guvnors at Windsor's Theatre Royal was cancelled due to flash-flooding, but the theatre director said the auditorium had been dried out and the show would continue on Wednesday night. The incident occurred after heavy rainfall on Tuesday, causing havoc in London and some people being trapped in cars. The festival celebrating 201 years of theatre in the Berkshire town was also affected.

Fiji is a country with a population of 876,000 and an area of 18,376 sq km. The official languages are English, Fijian, and Hindi, and the major religions are Christianity, Hinduism, and Islam. The country's currency is the Fijian dollar, and its president is Jioji Konousi Konrote, the first non-indigenous and the first elected by parliament. Prime Minister is Josaia Voreqe "Frank" Bainimarama, a former military leader who was elected as prime minister in a coup in 2014 after overthrowing the government of Laisenia Qarase.

A 17-year-old student in India was banned from attending her classes after she told a local media channel that political science is about cooking. Her parents were seen climbing school walls to pass on answers last year, and the government responded with fines and jail terms. However, when Ruby Rai's interview with the media was aired, the government suspended her and another student's results with immediate effect. The two students, as well as 12 others who excelled in the exams, will now have to appear for a written test and interview before a panel of subject experts on 3 June. Their handwriting will also be checked to verify if they answered their own questions.

Some 30 people have been living in tents on St Peter's Square in Manchester since April. Manchester City Council had issued a warrant to close the camp, and the protesters have now moved to St Anne's Square. Demonstrators want to highlight the crisis in temporary housing and the plight of homeless people. The camp has cost the council and police more than £88,000 in additional costs. The council has been working with the protesters to provide support and advice, and officers were present during the eviction to provide accommodation to those willing to accept it.

The Australian government sent two pieces of debris found by the public to Australia for analysis. The debris is consistent with drift modeling of how the plane may have been carried by ocean currents. The analysis has concluded the debris is almost certainly from MH370. The search for the plane continues, with 25,000 sq km of ocean still to be searched. The search is expected to be completed in the coming months.

The RMT union is planning two more days of strike action over a dispute with ScotRail over driver-only trains. Labour has urged RMT leader Humza Yousaf to meet with both parties to find a solution to the stalemate. Transport Scotland has said the minister has already engaged with both sides to find a solution. The RMT plans to hold two more strikes, on Sunday 24 and 31 July, after the failure of talks through the conciliation service Acas. Labour's transport spokesperson Neil Bibby said that rail passengers have already faced significant disruption this summer due to infrastructure work on the Queen Street tunnel and Glasgow Subway causing delays and cancellations. The new UK transport secretary said resolving the dispute on Southern Railways was his 'top priority'. The SNP government should start to take seriously the concerns of ScotRail staff and get a grip of the situation.

The Cavaliers are down 2-1 in the best-of-seven series after being defeated by Golden State. Kyrie Irving scored 30 points for the home team, while Steph Curry only managed 19. The Warriors coach Steve Kerr criticized the Golden State team for being too physical and punching the Cavaliers "right in the mouth." James said he was motivated by his team-mates to be more aggressive. Game four is scheduled for Friday in Cleveland.

The Official Charts Company reports that "The Tracks" by Kylie Goulding has become the UK's number one single, with 117,000 copies sold. It outsold its closest rival, Avicii's "Wake Me Up," which sold 77,000 copies. Lady Gaga's "Applause" was the second new entry on the chart, with 58,000 copies. Miley Cyrus's "We Can't Stop" was last week's number one and fell to third this week. The deluxe edition of Goulding's album "Halcyon" also climbed seven places to 19 on the chart. "Boom Boom" by Ray Foxx entered the top 20, while Arctic Monkeys' "Why'd You Call Me When You're High" and The Wanted's "We Own the Night" also entered the top 20. Britain's Got Talent duo Richard and Adam Johnson's album "The Impossible Dream" remained at the top of the album chart for a third consecutive week.

The council in Scotland has proposed cuts of £1.3 million to avoid these budget cuts, but other savings will be made. These include £500,000 by changing the council's policy on sickness absence and a further £500,000 in schools energy incentives. The Liberal Democrats had proposed cutting the pay of senior councillors, but their proposal was defeated. The ruling group, made up of independent councillors, proposed cuts in funding for deprived areas, street cleansing, homeless support, women's aid groups, and the Blas Music Festival. Many local authorities in Scotland accepted the Scottish government's funding deal worth £10.3 billion, but some did so reluctantly, claiming the continued council tax freeze would lead to severe pressure on budgets.

The Rev. Barry Trayhorn, a Christian minister from Sandy, was unfairly dismissed from his role as a gardening supervisor at a prison in Cambridgeshire in 2014. He claimed he had been invited to lead worship services at the prison and was reading a Bible passage on 31 May 2014 when a gay prisoner complained. Trayhorn continued to lead services until later that year, when he was told to attend a disciplinary hearing. He also reported being harassed due to his Christian faith. The case against the Secretary of State for Justice continues.

The Independent Inspector of Immigration has said the Home Office must improve its records of "overstayers," foreign nationals who are refused leave to stay in the UK. The report suggests that the number of overstayers in the UK is not increasing, but instead is remaining largely static. The Home Office signed a contract with private outsourcing group Capita to review and close the records of migrants who had been refused leave to stay in the UK. However, the report found significant inaccuracies in Capita's classification of migration refusal records. The number of overstayers in the UK is thought to have increased by 1,140 between 2013-14, due to the inaccuracies in the records. The report's recommendations will be taken forward, but changes made by the government have been having a positive impact and need to be judged over time.

The My Dentist practice in Dolgellau will be closing on March 31, and the town's other practice is private. The NHS practice has been unable to recruit a permanent dentist in the last two years, and the town's dentist will be unable to provide services at the Mervinian House Family Dental Practice. Betsi Cadwaladr Health Board plans to re-commission dental services in the area as soon as possible, but there is likely to be a gap between the end of the existing services and the completion of the tender exercise. The health board is therefore making arrangements for the provision of dental services on a cover basis until a permanent solution can be put in place, including a dental out-of-hours clinic. The Welsh Government expects the health board to continue to review and improve access to NHS primary care dental services through its 2016-17 Operational Plan.

Liam Day, 26, has gone missing during a climb near Durlston Country Park. Police and coastguard crews have searched for him extensively, but the search has been suspended. His partner has posted on Facebook that he might not return. Enquiries are ongoing, and the coastguard appeals to anyone who saw him. Climbing equipment was found west of Anvil Point.

The All-Ireland semi-final between Dublin and Donegal is expected to be a tactical game, with McGuinness's team facing an all-attacking style from Dublin. The Donegal manager believes that his players are capable of handling the challenge and says that the game is "one hundred per cent about football players." He is not concerned about being rated as rank 8/1 outsiders and is focused on getting things right for the game.

The report by High Fliers found that around 1,000 graduates turned down job offers at the last minute in 2015, leaving employers searching for replacements. The number of graduates hired rose 3.3% in 2015, with their starting salary at leading employers remaining at about Â£30,000 for the second year running. The report added that it's welcome news that Britain's top employers are recruiting their biggest-ever intake of new graduates in 2016, but as the job market goes from strength to strength, it's clear that our brightest graduates are becoming increasingly choosy about the employers they join.

A man was injured when he fell into the path of an oncoming train at Twickenham Stadium. He is not thought to be critically ill and was treated at the scene by London Ambulance. The man was later taken to St George's Hospital and the train that hit him was slowing down at the time. Services between Twickenham and London Waterloo were suspended while the man was treated, but later resumed. The incident occurred during the England's victory over Fiji in the first World Cup game.

Malta is a Mediterranean island that has a history of colonial control dating back centuries. It has been occupied by the Phoenicians, Greeks, Romans, Arabs, and later the French and British. In 1964, Malta gained its independence from Britain and in 2004, it joined the European Union. The island's strategic position has led to its development as an important trading post, and it remains a leading center for container and freight transhipment. Malta is also a popular holiday destination, with tourism accounting for the majority of the nation's income. The island has a population of 419,000 and an area of 316 sq km. The official languages are Maltese and English, and the major religion is Christianity. The current President of Malta is Marie-Louise Coleiro Preca, who was elected in April 2014 with the unanimous approval of parliament. The Prime Minister of Malta is Joseph Muscat, who took office in March 2013 after his Labour Party won a national election.

The 34-year-old actor, who stars in the new film Demolition, is at the Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF) to promote the festival which runs for 11 days. The festival, which has nearly 400 films, including the world premiere of Demolition on stage, has also featured Dallas Buyers Club, Wild, and Where to Invade Next. TIFF will culminate with its own awards ceremony, which is voted for by the ticket-buying public.

The Belfast Telegraph and Irish News report on various news stories in the week, including a boy with a brain condition who was injured in a petrol bomb attack and a controversial Stormont scheme for grants to Orange Halls. The Irish News also covers a story about a County Tyrone boy fighting life-threatening epilepsy and the use of cannabis oil by medical professionals to help him. Additionally, the News Letter reports on a prosecution decision in a case related to the Kingsmills massacre and an investigation into a suspect in the murders of 10 Protestant workmen in rural south Armagh.

A survey of 1,000 adults found that half of those who listen to music for more than an hour a day are at risk of developing tinnitus, which can cause a "constant roar" in the ears and head.Action on Hearing Loss warns that one in 10 people in the UK have the condition, which can affect their ability to concentrate and sleep. The charity is funding research into treatments and offers support to those who suffer from it.DJ Paul Oakenfold is supporting the campaign and urges people to wear ear defenders and turn down the volume on their music players.
France wins mixed team event at Hopman Cup, defeating United States 4-1 in doubles final. Gasquet and Mladenovic claim victory after defeating United States in women's singles and doubles matches.

Australia coach Malcom Jones has praised his side's performance in the Six Nations, saying they have a long-seated rivalry with England. Jones' first home match comes against Ireland at Twickenham on Saturday. He believes that within the England side, the rivalry can be useful, but he will not be using it. Jones also praised Manu Tuilagi, who he believes is best suited for the 12 shirt. England are currently level with France at the top of the Six Nations table.

Paramedics in Scotland treated approximately 12,000 people who were drunk between six months and the end of September, according to data obtained by the Scottish Conservatives under freedom of information laws. The Scottish Ambulance Service said alcohol had a significant impact on its operations and that it was often a key factor in call-outs. The figures highlight the "deep-rooted and complex" problem alcohol is causing in Scottish society, which is having a harmful effect on not only those who are over-consuming but also resources that could be better used for those in need. The Scottish government and NHS can do more to discourage excessive drinking and provide more support for paramedics who have to deal with it.

The text discusses economic inactivity in Northern Ireland, which refers to people who are not seeking work. The rate of economic inactivity in Northern Ireland is around 27%, which is slightly higher than the UK average of 22%. The government has launched a strategy called 'Enabling Success' to address this issue and increase employment levels in Northern Ireland to the UK average by 2030. The strategy will focus on three groups: those with work-limiting health conditions or disabilities, lone parents, and people with caring responsibilities.

The text discusses comments made by Donald Trump regarding John McCain, a former prisoner of war and war hero. Trump said he likes people who aren't captured, prompting criticism across the party. Rick Perry called the comments a "new low" in US politics. Trump later clarified his remarks, but did not apologize. The two have clashed before, with McCain accusing Trump of having "fired up the crazies" with his attacks on Mexican immigrants. Many of Trump's rivals for the Republican presidential nomination have lined up to attack him, and there are currently 15 people running to be the Republican presidential candidate.

Robert Kinsella, a Canadian author and poet who was best known for his baseball-themed fantasy novel "Shoeless Joe," passed away on Friday. He was 72 years old and had published more than 30 works of fiction and non-fiction. Kinsella won the Order of Canada, one of the country's highest honours. His novel was adapted into the 1989 film "Field of Dreams." After suffering a head injury in a car crash, Kinsella lost interest in writing fiction and instead spent his time playing Scrabble online. However, he did resume writing and his final work "Russian Dolls" is due to be released next year.

Máiría Cahill won a by-election in Northern Ireland's Senate after Jimmy Harte of the Labour party resigned. She won 122 of the 188 valid votes cast by serving senators and members of parliament. Last year, she revealed she had been forced into silence by the Irish Republican Army when she was 16. The man she accused of raping her was later acquitted of all charges. Ms Cahill is a member of one of the most prominent families of the Irish Republican Movement. After her election, she said she would invite sex abuse organizations to the senate to discuss support for victims and use her time to help young jobseekers in the country.

The offices of a children's counseling charity in Cardiff and Prestatyn received calls from boys worried about the effects of pornography on their lives. The charity, called Fight Against Porn Zombies, has launched a campaign to raise awareness of the issue. A UK-wide poll of 700 children showed that one in five had seen pornographic images that shocked or upset them. The charity's CEO says that children of all ages today have easy access to a wide range of pornography and if society shies away from talking about this issue, then they are failing the young people it is affecting.

Mariner Street car park will be cleared and replaced with a 725-bedroom student block, which will be the second tallest building in Swansea. The tower is expected to start construction later this year and finish by summer 2018. The project is seen as a major step forward for the regeneration of High Street in Swansea, as both Swansea University and Trinity Saint David universities are expanding in the city.

Heavy rain from Cyclone Debbie has caused floods in Queensland and New South Wales, with some areas partially submerged. Photos show residents surveying damage and using surfboards to navigate the floods. Several rivers have broken banks, and an evacuation order has been issued for Billinudgel, NSW. Businesses in South Murwillumbah have been inundated, and tens of thousands of people have lost power. The storm system has moved out to sea, but authorities say it is too early to estimate a damage bill.

American Airlines' pilot and co-pilot used software for viewing flight plans on iPad, but in 2013 the firm stopped working due to a glitch. The move saved the company more than $1.2m in fuel costs. The issue affected some flights, but the airline is still investigating the cause. Some airlines have switched to using tablets for flight planning, but there is competition among firms.

A court in Thane, Mumbai has convicted Girish Pote, 35, of the 2013 murder of his wife Madhuvanti Pathak. Pote killed his wife and chopped her body into pieces. The crime came to light after he telephoned relatives to confess to the crime and they informed the police. The judge said Pote would remain in jail for as long as he lived because of the "gruesome" nature of his crime. The couple married in 2006 and had a two-year-old son. They had been fighting over money and also because Pathak wanted to return to France.

Bradford Council has drawn up plans for a clockwise one-way gyratory along East Parade, Hanover Street, and Cavendish Street to combat the town's growing congestion problem. The plans will be displayed in the Airedale shopping centre on 11 and 13 June.

Thorpe, 23, could make his debut for Bradford against Millwall on Saturday. He has made seven appearances for the Millers this season, but last featured in a 5-2 defeat by Ipswich on 7 November. The Bantams are currently seventh in League One, outside the play-offs on goal difference.

A Spanish political leader was pranked by a radio presenter who pretending to be a Carles Puigdemont impersonator. The presenter was able to secure an audience with the prime minister, who agreed to meet with the fake leader. However, the meeting ultimately turned out to be a hoax and the prime minister was disappointed but still thanked the presenter for taking the joke well. This is not the first time a high-profile political figure has fallen for a prank phone call.

Lib Dem Baroness Hamwee asked if the £1 pay rate for immigration detention inmates was something to be proud of. Baroness Williams of Trafford told the Lords that the work was voluntary and helped meet recreational and intellectual needs, not to save money. She also argued that any rights detainees had to work were curtailed, so their pay rights were not the same as those who were not subject to immigration detention. The text concludes by stating that the money is not wages as it is being reviewed and a report is expected at the end of the year.

The winner of the 2017 Walter Scott Prize for Fiction will be announced at the Borders Book Festival later this year. The shortlist includes Jo Baker, Sebastian Barry, Charlotte Hobson, Hannah Kent, Francis Spufford, Graham Swift, and Rose Tremain. The judges said they had extended the list to seven titles due to the "variety of the longlist." The seven contenders are: A statement from the judges said: "Our shortlist was achieved by the judges' instinctive reaction to each book." These seven wonderful books encapsulate moments in history in truly unforgettable ways, making the 2017 Walter Scott prize shortlist one to savour. The winner receives Â£25,000, and shortlisted authors each receive Â£1,000. The second and final judges' meeting looks set to be as lively as the first.

Bangladesh needs only three more runs to secure their first Test win against England in Mirpur. The hosts are currently 2-22 in their second innings. England were bowled out for 240 in the second over of the match. Bangladesh responded with 253-8, with debutant Sabbir Rahman scoring 59. The umpires ended play due to bad light, but both teams played the game skillfully. The opening Test of the two-match series has already become notable for a world record number of decisions being reviewed. The second Test of the series will be played in Mirpur on Friday.

The University of Aberdeen's medical school has been in the center of a strike action over job security. Three-quarters of those who participated in the ballot voted for strike action, and a petition will be handed in on Tuesday. The university expressed disappointment at the announcement. A University of Aberdeen spokesperson said they will not allow the disruption of student exams and have made arrangements to avoid it. The remaining four staff members at risk of redundancy have been offered alternative employment on their current salary and grade, and no compulsory redundancies are now believed to be needed. The university is an equal opportunities employer and takes this responsibility seriously.

Jay Brenton Liptrot, 43, owns a property in Prestatyn, Denbighshire where five people died in October 2012. He did not enter a plea when he appeared at the town's magistrates' court on Friday. Melanie Smith, 30, has already been jailed for at least 30 years for starting the fire in a row over a shared hallway. Mr Liptrot will appear at Mold Crown Court in May.

A 34-year-old man was arrested at the Aberdeen Sea Cadets base at Pocra Quay. The incident was described as a "disgraceful incident" by police. The man was later freed from custody pending further inquiries and is expected to appear at Aberdeen Sheriff Court.

The "Read On. Get On." report warns that children who fall behind in reading are at risk of not getting good qualifications and going on to further education. The coalition behind the report aims to have all 11-year-olds reading well within a generation and is asking parents to read to their children for 10 minutes a day. The report found that 40% of families in the lowest income bracket had fewer than 10 children's books at home and that fathers from these households were less likely to read with their children at age two. The report says that this impacted on children later in life and that every child should have a fair and equal chance to learn to read well, regardless of their background. The most commonly read material by children is now text messages, with websites and e-books growing in popularity.

The 30-year-old forward has signed for the Giants and will join Mark Garside in committing to the franchise. Garside will stay with the team for an eighth year after spending four years with the Edinburgh Capitals. Martinelli is happy to be back and excited to chase trophies in his second season with the team. Garside has won two league titles in Belfast and helped the team win silver in the World Championship.

Rasmus Barlow, 16, was reported missing on Monday by his father leading to a large-scale search by police. His death is not being treated as suspicious and a file is being prepared for the coroner's office. Police said family liaison officers were continuing to support the teenager's family.

A 17-year-old student at a college in Wales was struck by his teacher, Regina Hungerford, after she lost her temper when he listened to music in her classroom. The incident resulted in a ruling by the Education Workforce Council that contact with the student is probably unacceptable and may put at risk the public trust in the profession. Hungerford's conduct was deemed " far from satisfactory" by the panel and she could face further disciplinary action.

Many brands are using the hashtag #MayThe4thBeWithYou to promote their products on May 4, in纪念《星际迷航》电影中的“May the Force be with you”台词。其中，一些品牌如British Museum、Heathrow Airport和Darth Vader本人也加入了这一活动。有些品牌甚至利用 actual Star Wars exhibit 来庆祝，如Former Dragons Den star Theo Paphitis。一些慈善机构也利用这个 hashtag 提高人们的意识。

Four retired generals and admirals have announced their support for Donald Trump, calling him the better candidate for commander-in-chief. Trump has been fined for not disclosing a political donation to Florida AG Pam Bondi. The Washington Post reports that Bondi had been considering fraud charges against Trump University in 2013, but dropped the investigation after a $25,000 contribution from the Donald J Trump Foundation. Trump and Clinton will both participate in a national security forum on Wednesday, where they will be asked questions by military service members. Clinton's campaign released a TV ad featuring a group of veterans critical of Trump.
The 21-year-old left-sided footballer signed a one-year contract with Championship club Tykes after being promoted from QPR. He had a brief loan spell with Colchester in the 2014-15 season.

The first novel in Philip Pullman's new trilogy, The Book of Dust, will come out in October. The trilogy is called The His Dark Materials and the story is about Lyra Belacqua, the protagonist of the series. The first book will be a continuation of the story that follows her from when she is a baby to when she is 20 years old. The trilogy has sold more than 17.5 million copies and will be translated into 40 languages. Mr. Pullman has not released the title of the first book yet, but the video above features him talking about the new trilogy.

A safety poster featuring black children not "cool" and white children "cool" has caused controversy. The American Red Cross released a statement apologizing for the misunderstanding and承诺 to be more sensitive in the future. The poster has been removed from their website and will no longer be printed.

The text discusses the appointment of Karl Winkelman as the new manager of MK Dons. Winkelman previously had doubts about whether the former player would remain in charge, but now believes he will be the manager next season. The text also mentions that Winkelman has already made mistakes with recruitment and that the club has more pressure than ever. Finally, he is excited about the fact that the club is becoming a bigger one and is looking forward to being a big club in League One next season.

The text discusses the involvement of two Scottish celebrities in the Edinburgh International Film Festival (EIFF). James Cosmo, who has starred in movies like Braveheart, and Karen Gillan, who used to play the role of Dr Who, have been named as EIFF honorary patrons. Mark Adams, the artistic director of the EIFF, expressed excitement about the addition of the two celebrities to the festival's illustrious list of patrons. James Cosmo said it was a "real honor" to be a part of the EIFF, while Karen Gillan expressed her excitement about her new role as a filmmaker. The text also notes that Karen Gillan moved to Edinburgh when she was 16 to study acting and developed a creative connection with the city.

The text reports on the comments made by England national team player Luke Rose, who said he and his team-mates at Tottenham were underpaid. Rose's comments were criticized by manager and chairman, and he apologized to the team, fans, and the chairman. Spurs have not signed any players yet this summer and have been boosted by the news that Kieran Trippier's ankle injury is not as bad as first feared.

The International Ski Federation imposed a punishment on Mae Vanakorn, a Thai-born British violinist, after she was found to have helped to manipulate results to ensure her place at the Sochi Olympics. An investigation was conducted into four Slovenian races, and Vanakorn and five officials were punished. The Singapore-born Vanakorn represented Thailand at the Sochi Winter Olympics and under her father's surname, Vanakorn. The Court of Arbitration for Sport will now consider the appeal. Last month, Vanakorn told BBC Sport that her ban was "nonsensical."

The game was opened by Rhys Browne in the seventh minute. The first half saw both teams creating chances but it remained 1-0 at the break. Macclesfield had the ball in the net seven minutes after the interval but the flag was up. Eastleigh nearly equalized in the 70th minute but the header clashed against the post. The second half saw substitute players and the game ended with Macclesfield taking the lead with a goal by Rhys Browne.

Warner Bros TV has failed to reach an agreement with several cast members over salaries for the long-running sitcom "The Big Bang Theory". However, the show's extension for a further three series has been announced. Parsons, Galecki, and Cuoco are seeking up to $1m per show, which would make them the highest paid actors on US television. The show's production may be delayed if new deals are not reached in the next two weeks.

Matthew Cobden, 38, appeared in Basingstoke Magistrates' Court after being charged with the manslaughter of Alexander Worth, 27, who was killed in a road traffic accident in August.
